Wrong, at least as far as Apple is concerned. The third-party app was far from perfect, but a flawed solution is surely better than no solution. Apple announced the AirPods in September 2016 alongside the iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus. Unfortunately, delays in production meant the Apple AirPods didn‚Äôt go on sale until December 2016. And that‚Äôs when we discovered Apple will charge you $69 Apple Will Charge You $69 for Lost AirPods Apple Will Charge You $69 for Lost AirPods It's almost as if this courageous decision to ditch the headphone jack is a license for Apple to print money. But that can't be true, can it?! Read More when you lose one of your AirPods. Despite looking decidedly odd ‚Äî like someone decided to snip the wire on your regular EarPods ‚Äî Apple‚Äôs AirPods are actually rather good. There‚Äôs just one problem (apart from the aforementioned aesthetics): it‚Äôs rather easy to lose one, or the other, or both. Apple‚Äôs AirPods just sit in your ears. They‚Äôre a snug fit, but if you jerk your head suddenly, or start doing rigorous exercise, one can easily fly out. We‚Äôre pretty sure you could also lose one down the toilet without too much trouble. Especially when inebriated. Finder for AirPods Gets Lost Working on the assumption people will lose their AirPods on a regular basis, an iOS developer called Deucks created an app called Finder for AirPods. This app uses the strength of the Bluetooth signal to help you find your lost AirPods. Or at least it did until Apple killed it. According to Reddit, Apple removed Finder for AirPods after the company deemed it ‚Äúnot appropriate for the App Store‚Äù. What that actually means is anyone‚Äôs guess, but don‚Äôt be surprised to find a similar solution included in a future iteration of iOS. In the meantime, anyone who has already purchased the Finder for AirPods app can request a refund from Apple How to Get a Refund from iTunes & Mac or iPhone App Stores How to Get a Refund from iTunes & Mac or iPhone App Stores Whether you're using an iPhone, an iPad, or a Mac, Apple has a simple, straightforward system to ask for refunds or return items you didn't want. Read More . However, if you own AirPods and don‚Äôt fancy having to shell out $69 every time you lose one, be sure to take damn good care of them. Do you own a pair of Apple AirPods? Have you mislaid one or both? Even temporarily? Did you purchase the Finder for AirPods app? What did you think of it? Why do you think Apple removed Finder for AirPods from the App Store? Steve Jobs iPhone The iPhone, credited with¬†redefining the mobile phone and helping make Apple one of the most valuable companies in the world along the way, marks its 10th anniversary today. Since it was¬†first unveiled in 2007, the company¬†has gone on to sell more than one billion units. Apple¬†has introduced 11 new generations of the iPhone, drastically redesigning the device on several occasions,¬†including the release of the first five-inch version in 2014. The phone also sparked the creation of the App Store, which launched in 2008 and has since been at the heart of the creation of a large number of hugely successful mobile app businesses, including the likes of Angry Birds, Uber and Deliveroo. It very nearly didn‚Äôt get off the ground.¬† How it all started On a stage in San Francisco, Steve Jobs, a balding tech genius in a black turtleneck¬†and blue jeans, holds up a shiny black device and tells the world that ‚ÄòApple Inc‚Äô, his newly renamed company, is about to¬†‚Äúreinvent the phone‚Äù. ‚ÄúEvery once in a while, a revolutionary product comes along that changes the world‚Äù, he tells the spellbound audience at the company‚Äôs annual MacWorld expo on January 9, 2007. It is a bold gamble, perhaps even a lie. The prototype Jobs holds up to the cameras barely works.¬†His entire demonstration is a carefully planned sham: a game of smoke and mirrors. If anyone in the audience gets their hands on it, the device is more likely to¬†freeze or randomly restart than work properly. For this reason, no one but Jobs is allowed to touch it. ‚ÄúThe most advanced phones are called smartphones, so they say. And they typically combine a phone plus some email capability plus they say it‚Äôs the internet, sort of the ‚Äòbaby‚Äô internet, in one device,‚Äù Jobs says. ‚ÄúThe problem is they‚Äôre not so smart and they‚Äôre not so easy to use.‚Äù The truth is, neither is the iPhone he is holding‚Äîone of fewer than 100 prototypes in existence. For weeks, his¬†team maps out a careful order of tasks they are reasonably certain the phone can handle. They call it the ‚Äúgolden path‚Äù. If Jobs does anything to the phone not on this list, or if he changes the order in any way, the device may crash, embarrassing him on the world stage. But if it works, Jobs may convince the tech industry, and a wider body of consumers, that Apple Inc really can deliver¬†‚Äúan iPod, a phone and an internet communicator‚Äù all in one. The gamble pays off. These secrets are divulged¬†in Battle of the Titans: How the Fight to the Death Between Apple and Google is Transforming our Lives, a 2013 book by tech journalist¬†Fred Vogelstein. ‚ÄúThere was even less they could do to make sure the phone call Jobs planned to make from the stage went through. All Grignon and his team could do was make sure the signal was good and pray. They had AT&T bring in a portable cell tower so they knew reception would be strong. Then, with Jobs‚Äô support, they preprogrammed the phone‚Äôs display to always show five bars of signal strength regardless of the true signal. The chances of the radio‚Äôs crashing during the few minutes that Jobs would use it to make a call were small, but the chances of it crashing at some point during the ninety-minute presentation were high.‚Äù‚ÄúThe software in the iPhone‚Äôs Wi-Fi radio was so unstable that [software engineer Andy] Grignon and his team ultimately soldered antenna wires to the demo phones and ran them offstage along the wires to the projection setup. The iPhone would still connect wirelessly to the network, but the signal wouldn‚Äôt have to travel as far. Even then, Grignon and his team needed to make sure no one in the audience could get on the frequency they were using,‚Äù Vogelstein writes. Apple launches the iPhone in June that year, with many (but not all) of the bugs ironed out. The first iteration comes in two models: the 4GB or 8GB. They are initially only available through Cingular Wireless, a subsidiary of AT&T, then the biggest telco in the US. Years later, in 2013, a team of researchers from the United Arab Emirates publish a paper that theorises there have been three great ages of the smartphone. The first age is when smartphones are only for business people, with email, fax, camera and limited internet, and no more. The defining moment of the second age, so says the paper, is the advent¬†of the iPhone, when portable computing is suddenly opened up to¬†the masses. Greg Christie, then a senior software engineer at Apple, has also revealed in recent years that the phone had a codename, and that Jobs jealously guarded its secrets. Scott Forstall, a senior member of Apple‚Äôs software team, reportedly approaches Christie in late 2004 to ask if he wants to work on a secret project called ‚ÄúPurple‚Äù. He agrees and joins a ‚Äúshockingly small‚Äù team. For several months, Christie meets Jobs twice a month in a windowless room on the second floor of Apple‚Äôs headquarters in Cuppertino, California. Only a handful of employees have access to the room, and cleaners are not allowed in. Security is tight.¬† Jobs reportedly demands that employees working on ‚ÄúPurple‚Äù at home must use a computer in a secluded part of the house to prevent anyone seeing details. All digital images are to be encrypted. Such has been the success of the iPhone that as an individual business the revenue generated by the phone alone exceeds that of some of its rivals, including Microsoft and Google. Increasing pressure from competitors‚Äîsome would even say outright plagiarism‚Äîhas eroded its market share. Sales of the iPhone dropped for the first time in its history in 2016. But its moment in history cannot be erased. Samsung rolls out new smart TV services for sports, music & video, plus an updated mobile app Posted Jan 9, 2017 by Sarah Perez (@sarahintampa) 0 SHARES Next Story Facebook to test showing ads mid-video with publisher revenue¬†split Apple last month released a new¬†TV app in an attempt to centralize all the streaming TV options available across Apple TV, iPhone and iPad. Now, Samsung is rolling out its own take¬†on the matter, with the launch of a trio of new Smart TV services focused on sports, music and video on demand. The services are a part of Samsung‚Äôs Smart Hub platform, which offers customers a¬†way to navigate live TV, video on demand, and apps. As a part of this launch, Samsung¬†will also update its Smart View app for iOS and Android, which offers a remote control, recommendations on what to watch, and other personalized notifications that work with the newly added services. Unlike Apple, Samsung, is able to bypass the need for a streaming media device because it built smart TV services directly into a number of its television sets. The company has now upgraded its¬†Smart TV platform with the launch of three services: Sports, Music and TV Plus. In some cases, these services even one-up Apple on functionality that its more limited TV app doesn‚Äôt have. For example, Samsung customers can customize the new Sports service to receive alerts about when their favorite teams are playing, then click a button to tune-in. These alerts are pushed to both the TV and the smartphone via the updated Smart View application. The latter makes it possible to receive alerts even if¬†your TV is switched off. Apple, meanwhile, also has a live tune in feature on Apple TV- you can tell Siri that you want to watch the game or ask her what games are on, and then the app streaming the game is launched for you. But Siri doesn‚Äôt know which teams you care about the most, or remind you to watch. Samsung says it‚Äôs working with partners on its Sports service, including NBC Sports, UFC and others. Samsung‚Äôs¬†new ‚ÄúMusic‚Äù service brings content from eight app partners to the smart TVs, including Spotify, iHeartRadio, Napster, Deezer, Sirius XM, Vevo, Melon and Bugs. Largely, this launch is focused on offering a more competitive app lineup to make Samsung TVs a more compelling alternative to standalone streaming media players, like Apple TV, Fire TV, Roku, Chromecast and others. However, the Music service has a few tricks of its own, too. Powered by Shazam, Samsung‚Äôs Smart TV users will be able to identify the songs you¬†hear on live TV or from the programs you‚Äôre¬†watching. The service will also include suggestions of new music you may like in the ‚ÄúPreview‚Äù section of the Smart Hub‚Äôs user interface. The third new service, TV Plus, was originally launched in Southeast Asia, but is now becoming available in the U.S. on select smart TVs, and will roll out to European users in April of this year. This feature of the Smart Hub platform is also somewhat competitive with Apple‚Äôs TV app as it aggregates TV and movie content from across services into a single interface. This includes on-demand TV shows as well as movies available for rent or purchase, like those from FandangoNow. Combined with Smart Hub‚Äôs ability to recommend shows you might like based on your prior viewing patterns, the updated platform across TV and mobile devices is not exactly a direct answer to Apple‚Äôs TV app, but it does attack the same overall¬†goal: making the TV experience more personalized to users. Personalization is the new battleground for today‚Äôs streaming platforms, all of which have increased their efforts in this space¬†in recent months. Roku‚Äôs ‚ÄúMy Feed‚Äù lets you follow TV shows and movies you want to track, while Fire TV suggests content¬†similar to what you‚Äôve been watching, thanks to Amazon‚Äôs recommendation engine. Apple TV uses its TV app to offer suggestions and point you to other popular content. The new services are launching in France, Germany, Italy, South Korea, Spain, the U.K. and the U.S., but exact details are still forthcoming in terms of dates and supported sets. 0 SHARES Advertisement Advertisement Crunchbase Samsung Electronics Founded 1969 Overview Samsung Electronics is a South Korean multinational electronics company engaged in consumer electronics, information technology and mobile communications, and device solutions businesses worldwide. The company develops, manufactures, and sells various consumer products, including mobile phones, tablets, televisions, Blu-ray players, DVD players, home theater systems, digital cameras, and camcorders; ‚Ä¶ Location Suwon, 17 Categories Medical Device, Hardware, Software, Electronics Website http://www.samsung.com/us Full profile for Samsung Electronics Newsletter Subscriptions The Daily ¬† Home U.K. News Sports U.S. Showbiz Australia Femail Health ¬† ¬† Science Money Video Travel Columnists Latest Headlines Science Pictures Discounts My Profile Logout Login Feedback DailyMail NEW ARTICLESHomeTop Share show ad Apple is accused of profiting from people's misfortune after removing a ¬£4 app that lets users find their lost ¬£159 AirPods¬† Finder for AirPods helped locate the wireless earphones using Bluetooth It was removed from the App Store by Apple, but the reason remains unclear The app's creator says Apple didn't like the idea of people locating their AirPods Apple charges ¬£65 ($69) to replace a single lost Airpod By Shivali Best For Mailonline Published: 11:33 EST, 9 January 2017 | Updated: 21:57 EST, 9 January 2017 e-mail 40 shares 114 View comments When Apple unveiled its wireless AirPod earphones in October, there were concerns about how easy it would be to lose the tiny devices. In a bid to help users keep track of their AirPods, an app called 'Finder for AirPods' was released, costing ¬£3.99 ($3.99).¬† But Apple has now removed the app, deeming it was 'not appropriate for the App store', although the reason remains unclear. Scroll down for video¬† In a bid to help users keep track of their AirPods, an app called 'Finder for AirPods' was released, costing ¬£3.99 ($3.99) FINDER FOR AIRPODS¬† Finder for AirPods used the earphones' Bluetooth signal to help users track them down. It would tell users when they were warmer or colder, using the signal strength as a measure. International Business Times UK UK LATEST NEWS Crime Property Culture Royalty World Latest News USA Europe Asia Africa Middle East The Americas Business LATEST NEWS Economy Companies Markets Finance Regulation Politics LATEST NEWS Fintech Latest news Blockchain Cryptocurrency Technology LATEST NEWS Smartphones Cybersecurity Innovation Social Media Games Motoring Science LATEST NEWS Space Environment Health Nature Archaeology Sport LATEST NEWS Football Tennis Golf Cricket F1 UFC Entertainment LATEST NEWS Movies Celebrity TV Music WWE Opinion LATEST NEWS Interview Analysis Reviews Video LATEST NEWS Business Technology Science Sport Entertainment Pictures LATEST NEWS Conflict Travel Arts Science Animal & Wildlife Photography Competition Log out Newsletter Signup Search Technology Smartphones IPhone Apple Steve Jobs Sleight of hand, white lies and a bottle of Scotch: How Apple pulled off the first iPhone launch As the iPhone turns 10, we revisit how Steve Jobs and Apple managed to make a buggy iPhone look finished. By Alistair Charlton January 9, 2017 16:07 GMT Apple co-founder Steve Jobs reveals the first iPhone on 9 January, 2007Reuters On 9 January 2007, Apple co-founder Steve Jobs took to the stage at the annual MacWorld event in front of 5,000 attendees to reveal the iPhone. Apple had been working on the handset in secret for two-and-a-half years, and such was the strength of its smoke-and-mirrors routine, engineers working on the hardware were kept separate from those designing the software. Hardly anyone know exactly what they were working on. Jobs had originally intended the iPhone's large touchscreen and software to be used on a tablet first, but on seeing what his engineers had produced decided a smartphone was more important. Days before the event rumours began circling that Apple was working on a phone, but such was Jobs' control not a single image, sketch or screenshot leaked. It was a different world compared to the near-full picture the rumour mills produce ahead of most Apple launches today. But Jobs' tight control over the iPhone's secrecy could not be matched by the design team's goal to have a fully working prototype on stage at MacWorld. Announced a full six months before going on sale (to avoid leaks via regulatory testing), the iPhone used by Jobs was barely functional. Engineers found a "golden path" where all of the phone's key functions could be shown off without it crashing, but only in one specific order. Surf the web before sending an email instead of the other way around, for example, and the iPhone would crash. And Jobs would likely have someone fired. A 2013 report by the New York Times Magazine, corroborated by The Internet History Podcast this week, revealed how the iPhone was so incredibly buggy that it was highly likely to crash during Jobs' one hour and 40 minutes on stage. Adding to the tension was Jobs' demand that a live stream of the demo iPhone was shown on a giant screen above the stage. This meant adding extra hardware to his iPhone and further complicating an already precarious situation. The iPhone's Wi-Fi software was so unstable that extra antennas were attached by long cables running off stage so the wireless signal didn't have to travel as far. Additionally, to stop the thousands of audience members trying to connect to the same network, it was configured to look like a Japanese signal, where Wi-Fi frequencies not available in the US are used. Jobs wanted to make a real phone call on stage, which meant network AT&T installing a portable cell tower on site. But even that wasn't enough for the Apple boss, so to make sure the phone's performance looked perfect the demo units were coded to display permanently five bars of signal coverage, regardless of how good their connection actually was. The golden path With just 128MB of memory (an iPhone 7 has 2GB, or 2,000MB) and running unfinished apps which were slow and bloated, the prototype iPhone was unlikely to make it through Jobs' demanding demo, where multiple features were used at once, in one piece. Through trial and error, engineers came up with the golden path, where an iPhone would survive to the end of the demo without crashing, but only if everything was shown off in the right order. Tap the wrong app by mistake and the phone would freeze or switch off completely. Although it looks like Jobs is casually scrolling through the phone's functions, he is carefully demonstrating each for just a few seconds to avoid overworking the handset. Several spare iPhones were also on stage, ready to take over if one crashed and needed to be reset. But for his final act Jobs wanted to play some music, take a call, put it on hold to take a second call, find and email a photo to the second caller, look up something online for the first caller, then return to his music. There was no room to switch to a second handset mid-demo; miraculously, the demo worked. 'We were in the fifth row doing shots of Scotch' Senior Apple engineer Andy Grignon, who was in charge of all wireless features of the iPhone, including phone signal, Bluetooth and Wi-Fi, recalls how he and his colleagues got increasingly drunk during the presentation. Speaking to the NY Times back in 2013, Grignon said: "And so there we were in the fifth row or something ‚Äî engineers, managers, all of us ‚Äî doing shots of Scotch after every segment of the demo. There were about five or six of us, and after each piece of the demo, the person who was responsible for that portion did a shot. When the finale came ‚Äî and it worked along with everything before it, we all just drained the flask...We just spent the entire rest of the day drinking in the city. It was just a mess, but it was great." Alongside CEO Dan Maag, as Chief Operating Officer (COO) Stefan Langefeld will be handling the already highly successful ongoing global rollout of the innovative video-on-demand (VoD) platform pantaflix.com particularly, while PANTALEON's CEO Dan Maag will focus more on the areas of strategy, international partnerships and production. Stefan Langefeld has more than 15 years of experience in the media and IT industry as a founder and manager, including around nine years in management positions at Apple, the biggest company in the world in terms of stock market value. Projects for which he was responsible included the launch of iTunes Video on German-speaking markets in Europe and more than 50 key emerging markets such as India, Africa, Russia, Turkey and the Middle East. With his comprehensive global network and his experience, he is considered one of Europe's leading managers in the field of VoD. He began his career as an Executive Assistant to the CEO at Medienholding EUVIA MEDIA AG. From there he joined SKY Deutschland before becoming Head of TV Germany at Apple in 2007, launching and managing the iTunes TV Store in Germany. The expansion of German-language business in Switzerland and Austria was followed in 2013 by the position of iTunes' Head of TV and Movies Central and Eastern Europe, which included the German-speaking countries, Italy and Eastern Europe. In October 2016, he became the Head of Apple Music and iTunes, assuming responsibility for the music business in German-speaking territories. "In Stefan Langefeld, we have secured one of the world's foremost minds in the field of VoD for our company," announced Mathis Schultz, Chairman of the Supervisory Board of PANTALEON Entertainment AG. "Mr Langefeld's commitment highlights the significance of pantaflix.com for the Group's ongoing growth. Especially in this phase of rapid growth, we are confident that we can benefit from Stefan Langefeld's expertise and outstanding network. We very much look forward to working together." "We have always been confident of the enormous potential of pantaflix.com. Nonetheless, the massive popularity since its launch in December 2016 has exceeded all our expectations. Securing a key player in the international VOD industry is therefore the next logical step in the rapid and solid growth of our global platform. Thanks to Stefan Langefeld we are now excellently positioned in the competition," said PANTALEON's CEO Dan Maag. "PANTALEON has become one of Europe's fastest growing media companies in recent years. I am especially pleased to be helping to shape the further development of the company in a key position moving ahead," said the future Executive Board member Stefan Langefeld. "I will contribute my experience from my work to date to expand pantaflix.com into a leading VoD company on the world stage." About pantaflix.com [1]: www.pantaflix.com [2] is an innovative and cloud-based Video-on-Demand (VoD) platform, which for the first time enables filmmakers and rights owners to market their productions to a worldwide audience with just a few clicks. pantaflix.com [1] offers immediate market access reducing the stages of the exploitation chain. 75 percent of sales go straight to the producer, 25 percent to pantaflix.com [1]. Thus, producers receive up to 7.5 times as much revenue as from traditional platforms. About PANTALEON Entertainment AG: PANTALEON Entertainment AG is one of the fastest growing media companies in Europe. The group, as a leading producer of feature films with world-class distribution partners such as Warner Bros. and Amazon Prime, developed high growth dynamics from the start. The financial success of the content division paid in for the formation of the disruptive video-on-demand (VoD) game changer pantaflix.com [1], a 100% daughter of PANTALEON that just recently initiated its global rollout. Home Mail Flickr Tumblr News Sports Finance Celebrity Answers Groups Mobile More Yahoo Search Search 0 Mail Tech Home Follow Us Reviews How To Deals Video Games Pogue Apple All the reasons people are ditching Android and switching to iPhones Zach Epstein BGR NewsJanuary 9, 2017 Reblog Share Tweet Pin it Share Apple‚Äôs first-generation iPhone started a revolution 10 years ago today. It seems like just yesterday that late Apple co-founder Steve Jobs walked out on stage at the Macworld conference in January 2007 and put an end to years of rumors and speculation. More importantly, Apple¬†put an end to overcomplicated smartphones like Symbian phones and BlackBerry handsets, shifting the industry toward¬†a much more intuitive user experience. Smartphones were once a necessary evil that professionals had to endure. Today, smartphones are the center of our digital lives and¬†most people can‚Äôt imagine spending even a moment without one. Of course Apple isn‚Äôt the only company that enjoyed success as a result of the iPhone‚Äôs introduction. Google, which had been developing Android as a BlackBerry clone, completely changed the direction of the platform ahead of launch thanks to the iPhone. Samsung grew to become the top handset maker in the world thanks in large part to copying Apple‚Äôs iPhone. But there‚Äôs still only one original, and Apple‚Äôs iPhone continues to draw users away from rival platforms to this day. Don't Miss: Apple‚Äôs iPhone turns 10 With a combined global user base currently in the billions, Google‚Äôs Android platform and Apple‚Äôs iOS platform see plenty of switchers flow between platforms. Some people ditch Android and switch to iOS, others¬†ditch iOS and switch to Android, and plenty of people move from one platform to the other and then switch back. Today, however, a big discussion over on Reddit draws focus to the flow of users in one particular direction: From Android to the iPhone. Reddit user ‚ÄúChondrule‚Äù received an¬†iPhone 7 Plus as a gift during the holidays, but he had been an Android user since his first smartphone. As he tried to decide whether or not to dump his Android phone and make the leap to iOS, he took to the Apple subreddit and asked former Android users to explain what made them jump ship and switch to an iPhone. Ironically, the user ultimately decided that he was going to stick with Android and not switch to the new iPhone 7 Plus he was gifted. But the Reddit thread he started¬†had nearly 500 comments at the time of this writing, and it gives a terrific insight into the many reasons people have decided to switch from Android devices to the iPhone. Not surprisingly, platform¬†updates are a huge draw for iOS and the iPhone, and many people listed this as the main reason for leaving Android behind. Because Apple controls both the hardware and software experiences on the iPhone, and because the company used its early momentum to force carriers‚Äô hands, Apple is able to push out software updates to all of its smartphones at once.¬†Meanwhile, Android users have to wait several months ‚Äî at least ‚Äî before new versions of Android are available for their handsets. Many people also noted that Apple supports its older iPhone models for much longer than Android vendors, which means they continue to receive software updates even years after their initial release. Another top reason listed in the thread is customer support; Apple is famous for industry leading customer service, offering post-sale support that no other company can match. Other popular reasons mentioned on Reddit include a general degradation of the Android user experience over time, battery life, and service lock-in thanks to features like iMessage and Continuity. This is partly due to upgrading to a new iPhone 7 Plus and having access to the unimaginably useful¬†‚ÄúHey Siri‚Äù hands-free functionality Make the Most of Hands-Free "Hey Siri" on Your iPhone or iPad Make the Most of Hands-Free "Hey Siri" on Your iPhone or iPad Here's how Apple's hands-free "Hey Siri" command can make your life easier. Creating a¬†Shopping List Creating a list is really easy, and because our smartphones generally take an organizational role in our lives, we‚Äôll be running through the process on an iPhone. Thanks to Apple‚Äôs unified design philosophy Should Mac Users Always Buy iPhones? Should Mac Users Always Buy iPhones? Read More , the process is¬†virtually identical on a Mac or the iCloud¬†website. Launch the Reminders app¬†and display all of your lists (tap the name of the currently-open list to close it). Assuming you don‚Äôt already have a ‚ÄúShopping‚Äù list, pull down from¬†on the list to reveal the plus ‚Äú+‚Äù icon. Tap it, select List,¬†name it¬†‚ÄúShopping‚Äù, choose a color, and hit¬†Done. You can also rename any of your other lists by tapping one, hitting¬†Edit and calling it whatever you like. You can then add things¬†to your list the old-fashioned way: tap the next blank line, type something, hit enter to move on to the next item, repeat. If you tap on an item you can hit the¬†i button to do other things, like set location reminders or be alerted at a specific time How to Set Up Location Alerts in iPhone Reminders How to Set Up Location Alerts in iPhone Reminders Set location-based alerts using the iOS Reminders app and never forget to buy bread or pick up a package ever again. Read More . You can also add notes about the item if you want to, but that‚Äôs about as deep as the app goes. Use Siri to Add Items &¬†View Your List You can add items to your¬†list by telling Apple‚Äôs assistant something like, ‚ÄúAdd bread to my shopping list‚Äù. Access Siri by holding down the Home button, or use the feature to its fullest potential with¬†the hands-free ‚ÄúHey Siri‚Äù command. This is especially useful if you‚Äôre cooking or doing something that means you can‚Äôt tap away on your phone. You should also speak naturally when adding items.¬†There‚Äôs no need to¬†pause after saying ‚ÄúHey Siri‚Äù to wake the assistant up ‚Äî just speak your full sentence. This feature only works on the iPhone 6s or later. One limitation to adding items to your list using Siri is the inability to add multiple items at once. If you ask Siri to ‚Äúadd bread and wine to my shopping list‚Äù then you‚Äôll get a single item for ‚Äúbread and wine‚Äù ‚Äî and¬†based on my testing, instructions like ‚Äúcomma‚Äù or ‚Äúplus‚Äù¬†make no¬†difference. This removes the requirement to stop what you‚Äôre doing and launch the Reminders app. Unfortunately¬†Siri is a bit over-zealous and starts reciting the entire list aloud until you check items off or ask something else. You can use Siri to manage all kinds of lists, and this works because we specifically created a ‚Äúshopping‚Äù list in the reminders app. If you‚Äôd prefer to use terms ‚Äúgrocery‚Äù or ‚Äúfood‚Äù instead, create lists with these titles. Other ideas include ‚Äúhousehold‚Äù or ‚Äúholiday‚Äù and even store names if you find yourself frequenting the same retailers. Make Your List Collaborative What makes the feature really useful is the fact that you can share your lists with other people who can add items¬†and check things off.¬†This obviously works best if all members have iPhones, particularly where groceries are concerned. To share your list with others: Launch¬†Reminders and find your list. Hit¬†Edit followed by¬†Sharing. Use the¬†Add person‚Ä¶¬†button to share¬†via email (use Apple ID emails for best results). Anyone you invite will receive an invitation on their device, and once accepted, they will be able to add items and mark others as completed.¬†You can also revoke access via the¬†Edit panel if you ever need to. When another person makes changes to the list,¬†changes will be reflected for all other collaborative users.¬†For instant changes, make sure you¬†enable¬†Push under¬†Settings > Reminders > Accounts > Fetch New Data.¬†Fetch might be easier on your battery How to Fix Poor iOS 10 Battery Life How to Fix Poor iOS 10 Battery Life Battery life not quite what it was before you updated? Unfortunately, there‚Äôs no desktop app integration available via these platforms.¬†If you‚Äôre¬†most likely going to be organizing things using your iPhone, though, this¬†won‚Äôt¬†be a dealbreaker for you. The Best Shopping List for iPhone¬†Users Apple‚Äôs own Reminders app, coupled with iCloud sharing, is the best list management solution for iPhone users. Deep integration with the rest of the OS, access from Siri, and the ability to sync with Mac and web clients makes for a surprisingly robust package. Sure there are more feature-rich solutions on the App Store, like AnyList¬†(Free), but¬†the core functionality isn‚Äôt necessarily any¬†better than¬†Apple‚Äôs own free app. The app that everyone with an iPhone already has, that makes sharing a breeze. Staying In Tech and Gaming 10 ways the iPhone has changed our world in the last 10 years Apple‚Äôs revolutionary smartphone has changed our lifestyles considerably Ben Travis Monday 9 January 2017 16:06 BST Click to follow ES Entertainment 10 years of Apple's iPhone 7 show all 10 years of Apple's iPhone 1/7 Unveiled Steve Jobs with the first iPhone AFP/Getty Images 2/7 iPhone The original iPhone Screen size 3.5in, rear camera 2 megapixel PA 3/7 iPhone 3G Screen size 3.5in, rear camera 2 megapixel AFP/Getty Images 4/7 iPhone 4 Screen size 3.5in, rear camera 5 megapixel Getty Images 5/7 iPhone 5 Screen size 4in, rear camera 8 megapixel Getty Images 6/7 iPhone 6 Screen size 4.7in, rear camera 8 megapixel Getty Images 7/7 iPhone 7 Screen size 4.7in, rear camera 12 megapixel PA Our world today moves fast, and it‚Äôs only speeding up ‚Äì it‚Äôs likely the 21st century will be looked at as a time when the world was available at our fingertips at all times. There‚Äôs one device in particular that‚Äôs been pivotal in this new pace of life¬†‚Äì the Apple iPhone, which changed technology, computing, and impacted our lifestyles in ways that few might have predicted. While it sparked a whole slew of similar products and operating systems, the original iPhone handset was the one that paved the way for everything that came after. Ten years on from the day that Steve Jobs first introduced the iPhone in one of his iconic presentations, here are ten ways it‚Äôs changed our world in the last decade. iPhone marks 10th anniversary Read more Google Pixel smartphone sees Londoners queue from 6am for iPhone rival 1) Apps One of the main keys to the success of the iPhone were apps ‚Äì which didn‚Äôt arrive until the launch of iOS 2.0. Apps meant that developers could create their own iPhone-accessible software and put it out there for people to use, and users could download extra functionality and games for their phones. Now apps allow us to do‚Ä¶ well, pretty much anything: book a taxi, order a pizza, edit a photo, download music, stream TV, and catch virtual Pokemon. (Niantic / Pokemon Company) 2) Selfies Gone are the days of grainy self-portrait photos taken in mirror reflections (sorry Tom Hardy).¬†The iPhone 4 brought the front-facing camera to smartphones in 2010, accounting for the majority of the photos currently clogging up your Instagram. 3) Emojis Emoticons were always a thing, but Emoji took the art of sending smiley faces to another level. The ever-expanding set of Unicode chracters was named in 2015 as the fast growing language in the world, allowing us to communicate in ways that words sometimes can't. (emojipedia) 4) Full internet access Remember WAP? Waiting five minutes for a low-res version of MySpace or Google to load? The iPhone saw an end to that¬†with a full mobile version of Apple‚Äôs Safari browser that meant you could do nearly everything you wanted to on the internet. It also changed the way the web was built ‚Äì now most websites are designed¬†in mobile-responsive code to fit the size of your screen, and Adobe Flash (famously not supported by Apple) has hugely decreased in prevalence. 5) GPS maps The arrival of GPS technology crossed with the arrival of apps meant never getting lost again.¬†The Google Maps app, and later Apple‚Äôs own Maps and Citymapper mean we always know where we‚Äôre meant to be going and exactly how to get there. iPhone marks 10th anniversary 6) Autocorrect Back in the pre-iPhone days, you had to press the #1 key three times to type a ‚ÄòC‚Äô. Nowadays we jab vaguely on a digital QWERTY keyboard, and autocorrect takes care of the rest ‚Äì 90% of the time typing exactly what we intended, and 10% of the time giving us embarrassing gaffes sure to go viral online. 7) Finger-accurate touch screens Touch screens were around back when the iPhone was first announced, but they often required a stylus to be used effectively and accurately. Steve Jobs was keen to stress the quality of the finger-activated multi-touch screen at the iPhone launch.¬†Now the stylus¬†in Apple‚Äôs tablet range is an artist‚Äôs design implement to be used on the tooled-up iPad Pro. Five things to know about the new iPhone 7 8) Instant music access The arrival of iTunes on PC¬†and Mac¬†was a huge moment in music downloads ‚Äì and the iPhone only increased the ability to instantly hear the latest songs. The iTunes Store app meant that iPhone users could download songs straight to their phone without the need to plug it into their computer first, while the Spotify app and Apple Music mean subscribers can listen to any song, anywhere. 9) Apple Pay It‚Äôs not been around for long, but the Apple Pay system is already looking like it could be a catalyst to the world becoming cash-free. iPhone owners who connect their bank card to their mobile can pay for TfL travel and shopping by waving their handset in front of a contactless pay point. Read more 2 nasty bugs are destroying iPhone battery life How to stop your iPhone running out of data Apple iOS 10: release time, what's new and how to install 10) Killing off other tech The iPhone hasn‚Äôt just created¬†new technologies¬†‚Äì in expanding the definition of what a phone could be, it‚Äôs incorporated so many other devices we‚Äôd usually own. It‚Äôs a camera, it‚Äôs an iPod, it‚Äôs a portable video player ‚Äì and you probably wouldn‚Äôt buy those things separately today. Not subscribed? ¬† ¬† Newsletters Account details Contact support Sign out ¬† Vendor Apple misses 2016 internal revenue, profit goals Top brass takes 55 percent hit to cash incentives from 2015 DH Kass 09 January 2017 Tweet ¬† Facebook ¬† LinkedIn ¬† Google plus ¬† Send to ¬† 0 Comments Apple fell short of its internal sales and operating profit targets for 2016, triggering an 11 percent cut in the cash incentive packages of its top brass, according to a Schedule 14A regulatory filing¬†submitted Friday. For the fiscal year ended 24 September 2016, Apple recorded net sales of $215.6 billion and operating income of $60 billion. The vendor's sales target for incentive payouts was $223.6 billion and the operating income goal was $60.3 billion, the document said. Related articles Apple misses 2016 internal revenue, profit goals Elliott Management takes $1.4 billion stake in Cognizant, pushes for changes Apple smashes Q4 with record results Today's channel rundown - 2 June 2016 As a result, the iPhone maker paid out annual cash incentives for 2016 at 89.5 percent of target, according to the SEC filing. It was the first time the company didn't pay out full cash incentives to its top executives in seven years. If Apple had hit its targets, CEO Tim Cook¬†would have received $6 million in cash incentives. CFO Luca Maestri, retail SVP Angela Ahrendts, SVP of internet software and services Eddy Cue, SVP of hardware engineering Dan Riccio and SVP and general counsel Bruce Sewell¬†each would have received an additional $2 million. All had the potential to receive $4 million in total cash incentives if the company had reached its maximum performance goals. Cook could have been granted $12 million in cash payouts. As it was, Cook, who has a base salary of $3 million,¬†received $5.4 million, while the the remaining executives, who are paid a minimum of $1 million annually,¬†took home $1.8 million in performance-based cash incentives, or 55 percent less than each was granted in fiscal 2015. If the vendor's revenue had slipped below the threshold level of $203.3 billion and operating profit dipped under $50.7 billion, none of the executives, including Cook, would have received the cash incentive bonus. Apple calculates the cash incentives of its top executives, including Cook, based on net sales and operating income results against threshold, target and maximum performance goals as set by a compensation committee. Apple paid Cook $8.75 million in total 2016 compensation, a notable dip from the $10.3 million the CEO made in 2015. Apple will release three new iPads this year: a second-generation, 12.9-inch Pro model; a lower-priced, 9.7-inch version of the iPad Air; and a new, ‚Äúhigh-end‚Äù 10- to 10.5-inch version with a narrowed bezel design, KGI Securities analyst Ming-Chi Quo said¬†in a research note. The new iPads are slated to be released in the second quarter, according to 9to5 Mac, an Apple blog that first reported on the analyst‚Äôs note over the weekend. Unlike the iPhone, the iPad doesn‚Äôt get regular yearly updates, which keeps Apple fanatics guessing on the timing. KGI expects iPad shipments in 2017 will drop about 10 percent to between 35 million and 37 million units. Still, that‚Äôs an improvement¬†over the 20 percent drop the iPad suffered in 2016, the firm noted. The new, 10- to 10.5-inch model could help Apple narrow the iPad‚Äôs sales declines this year if it gets demand from ‚Äúcommercial/enterprises,‚Äù according to the note. Indeed, the use of the iPad as a replacement for cash registers in restaurants and retail shops has helped prop up demand for the device in recent quarters. The 9.7-inch model, meanwhile, will be a lower-priced legacy option that will ‚Äúlikely account for 50 to 60 percent of total shipments of new iPads,‚Äù according to the report. The analyst notes that Samsung will be the ‚Äúbiggest winner‚Äù among ‚Äúnew-entrant‚Äù suppliers for chips in the lower-priced, 9.7-inch iPad. Last week, Samsung said it expects its quarterly profits to soar 50 percent despite its exploding-phone debacle last fall, propped up by solid sales of chips for devices from other companies including Apple. Sunday , 15 January 2017 Contact Privacy policy Terms of Use Disclaimer Information Copyright (DMCA) Our Staff Canada Journal ‚Äì News of the World Articles and videos to bring you the biggest Canadian news stories from across the country every day home Canada World Entertainment Health Science Sports Movies ‚Äì Series Technology Money Press Releases Home ¬ª Technology ¬ª Canada‚Äôs Competition Bureau closes two-year Apple investigation Canada's Competition Bureau closes two-year Apple investigation Canada‚Äôs Competition Bureau closes two-year Apple investigation Posted by: News Jan 9, 2017 in Technology Leave a comment After two years of investigation, Canada‚Äôs competition watchdog has decided to close its probe on Apple last Friday. A 24-month probe finally ended on Friday after Canada‚Äôs Competition Bureau on Friday said it was unable to gather sufficient evidence to prove Apple had taken part in anti-competitive actions. Apple was accused of using its market force to demand carriers sell rival devices at inflated prices. Other concerns centered around limitations Apple placed on marketing and sales of the iPhone by the carriers. The Canadian query surrounding the iPhone marketing and sales restrictions on carriers was very similar to investigations in France, South Korea, alleging the same things. Apple‚Äôs Canadian operations were under investigation from the country‚Äôs Competition Bureau, which was looking into claims of anti-competitive deals struck in the Country. The investigation was announced by the bureau in December 2014, with no presumed guilt. At the time of the investigation, the iPhone was available on main carriers Rogers, Bell, and TELUS, and on smaller providers Virgin Mobile, Fido, and Koodo. Last year we saw the additions of a bunch of new products like ceiling fans from Hunter, several new iDevices products, FirstAlert‚Äôs HomeKit safe, a whole range of switches and sensors from Elgato (that we reviewed), and much more. This year there are even more new products, which is very promising.¬†Admittedly while there are lots of new entrants, not everything is as original as a ceiling fan or safe. Instead we are seeing a lot of products that are making the HomeKit¬†ecosystem more seamless, and giving you options when you look for something like a lock, thermostat, or wall switch. Ring Floodlight Camera Starting with one of the products¬†I was most excited in and that looked most unique was the first HomeKit product from Ring. Previously known as Doorbot, the Ring Video Doorbell has been around a while. It has proven to be very popular, but lacked HomeKit support. They now have released a new floodlight, that has a built-in camera, that utilizes the enhancements Apple made to HomeKit in iOS 10. Namely, camera support. Other than HomeKit support, it also features 1080p video recording and the ‚Äúloudest siren available on an outdoor camera‚Äù. We‚Äôve seen other cameras take advantage of HomeKit but this is the first security floodlight camera we‚Äôve seen hit the market. iDevices Stick on Wall Switch iDevices has some really solid HomeKit products out there already. I‚Äôve used their outdoor switch for the past 2 years to control my Christmas lights with fantastic results. No longer do I need some odd remotes, or confusing schedules to control the lights. I can use the HomeKit app and Siri to have them turn on and off when I please. This year iDevices has another unique product I‚Äôm very excited to add to my smart home. That is the stick-on wall switch. We‚Äôve seen many physical wall switches that involve replacing your existing switches, but you are forced to use that location and can be tricky for many to do the wiring safely. These new stick-on switches will control any accessories or scenes you choose, and you don‚Äôt have to do have any existing wiring, or replace any existing hardware. They are powered from 2 coin cell batteries that will get you 2 years of use before you have to swap them. Like many HomeKit accessories, the biggest problem is they are still a bit pricey to change over your entire ouse at $49.95 a piece. They will be made available in mid 2017. Focalcrest Mixtile Hub Hubs are a necessary evil that we saw lots of this year at CES. The Mixtile hub is very different though because it allows you to connect your existing (but not HomeKit eligible) products using Z-Wave or ZigBee and connect them to HomeKit. There is an abundance of products using these two standards including thermostats, garage door openers, and especially lights. Mixtile hub is also unique as that you can actually connect it to your TV as a monitor to help the setup process. Then an accompanying app allows you to designate what each accessory does so it can be appropriately utilized via Siri and HomeKit. Incipio CommandKit Smart Wall Switch & Outlets Incipio announced a new wall switch, similar to what we‚Äôve seen in the past. What I thought was more exciting was the power strip. It allows you to connect 4 devices and control them individually through HomeKit. They could be different lights, fans, humidifiers, etc. All of which can be scheduled, triggered, or controlled. They will be viable later this year for $59.99 (Smart Wall Switch) and $99.99 (Power Strip). Elgato Eve Extend and Aqua I really like Elgato‚Äôs lineup of Eve HomeKit accessories. I currently utilize several of them to perform different functions around my home. They have been very reliable, and they look very nice. I particularly like their version on the popular wall switch that even includes a little nightlight. They‚Äôve built upon their already solid lineup of products with a new water sensor, and more interestingly, a Bluetooth extender. HomeKit products are made available outside your home by connecting to an Apple TV (or iPad running iOS 10). Problem is, not everything is necessarily within range of one of those two items. Say you have sensors or a lock on your door, but your Apple TV is in the living room. You can‚Äôt send commands or receive notifications when you are outside your home in that situation. The Eve Extend bridges those bluetooth products to Wi-Fi, allowing you access in those remote locations of your house. Netatmo Smart Smoke Alarm Netatmo makes some solid weather and camera products, but this is their first HomeKit-enabled product, and one many people were looking for. The Smart Smoke Alarm is similar to other ‚Äúsmart‚Äù smoke detectors that alerts you on your phone of problems and allows you to ‚Äúhush‚Äù the siren in the case of a false trigger from something like burnt toast. It has an 85db chime and a 10-year battery. HomeKit support will allow you to receive those notifications remotely, or even perform other functions like turning your smart bulbs red if it detects a fire. Chamberlain Hub and Smart Garage Door Opener Similar to how Philips released a new hub that added HomeKit support to their existing smart bulbs, Chamberlain is introducing a new MyQ Home Bridge that allows you to now use Siri with any of your already purchased accessories. They are even releasing the hub at a reduced price ($49.99), before raising it to full retail $69.99. More tempting¬†to me though, the smart garage door opener, dubbed the Smart Garage Hub. It allows you to add HomeKit support to virtually any brand of garage door system you already own. This is a perfect smart home accessory. You can tie it to location based commands, like if you arrive or leave it can open or close. Or even get notifications when someone raises or lowers it, similar to a window/door sensor. The Smart Garage Hub will be available starting April of this year. Withings¬†Home Plus Smart Security Camera Withings‚Äô popular baby monitor/smart security camera got a neat upgrade not too long ago that allowed you to watch it on your Apple TV. The newer Home Plus Smart Security Camera adds even more via HomeKit support. Yale Real Living Assure smart locks Joining Kevo, August, and a bevy of other manufactures, well known lock maker Yale is adding HomeKit support to their line of Real Living Assure smart locks. Leviton light switch Another iteration of the popular HomeKit light switch that we have seen a few times so far this year. Noticeably, they are more physical with actual clicking buttons unlike the capacitive button on the Elgato Eve. Carrier C√¥r thermostat Carrier introduced two new versions of their¬†C√¥r thermostats, bringing with them HomeKit support. It will be available early this year. ConnectSense Bluetooth Extender This is very similar to the Eve Extend, and allows you to connect your Bluetooth Low Energy based HomeKit products to Wifi, allowing even greater access. It adds to the already existing lineup of HomeKit sensors from ConnectSense. Fibaro‚Äôs Flood Sensor, Door/Window Sensor and Motion Sensor Fibaro has the most new entries into the HomeKit market this year with a flood sensor, motion sensor and a door/window sensor. While they aren‚Äôt the most exciting bunch of products, they are all necessary pieces of making a truly smart home. Now that iOS 10 includes triggers for things like door sensors, there is much more you can do. For instance, I have my patio lights turn on any time I open my patio door. The motion sensor in particular is also especially well equipped. It not only detects motion, but temperature, light intensity, and even an accelerometer to detect any tampering. The motion sensor will retain for $69.99, the door/window sensor for $59.99, and the flood sensor for $69.99. D-Link Omna D-Link is also stepping into the arena with their new HomeKit equipped Omna camera. The one product¬†I did expect to see here at CES that I didn‚Äôt was the Canary Plus security camera, which was expected to launch in the fall, alongside iOS 10. Summary I‚Äôm very happy with my HomeKit-equipped smart home and the array of products that we are seeing is starting to bring everything together. Early on it was a bit sketchy with mostly outlets and smart bulbs building out the product offerings. But if you had smart bulbs, you couldn‚Äôt use wall switches¬†lest¬†the ‚Äúsmart‚Äù features wouldn‚Äôt work, as you had cut off their power.¬†Now that we are having a more robust list of options for wall switches and sensors, it is about time we start seeing more accessories taking to HomeKit. I particularly want to see Apple and manufacturers start building HomeKit into things like smart coffee makers, ovens, safes, or other areas of the Home. Why not HomeKit enabled deadbolts? Or a dishwasher? It would be nice to load the dishwasher and have it scheduled to run overnight, or when I actually go to bed and forget that I didn‚Äôt start it, I can using Siri. So what do you think of the laundry list of new HomeKit products? Is it enough for you to dive in and start teaching your home new tricks? What other products would you like to see equipped with Siri control? Let us know all your thoughts down in the comments below. You can fix a frozen iPhone in 10 seconds without a computer or any other accessories so that you can get back with your day. You can also use this to fix a frozen iPad. Advertisement Sometimes a frozen iPhone will not let you do any type of activity, and often you are stuck on-screen in an app or on a home screen. This can also help if your iPhone is stuck off and won‚Äôt turn on, but mainly you will use this when the iPhone is stuck on with an app or something on-screen. This is a hard-reboot, but some people will call it a hard-reset. Don‚Äôt worry about the reset part of this name. You are not resetting the iPhone like you would with a factory reset that wipes all the data clean. Fix your frozen iPhone in seconds. This may not solve all of your problems. If the iPhone freezes regularly you may need to remove an app or perform an actual factory reset on your¬†iPhone and start from scratch. It‚Äôs normal for an iPhone to freeze once or twice in a year after you install a bad app or run into a problem. If things continue to freeze or go bad, there may be a hardware problem that requires a trip to an Apple Store. Advertisement Fix a Frozen iPhone in 10 Seconds You can fix a frozen¬†iPhone in about ten seconds by pressing and holding the power and home button at the same time until the iPhone restarts. Once the iPhone screen changes from the frozen state to showing an Apple logo or just a blank screen you can let go. This is a hard reboot. By pressing and holding the home button and power button you force the iPhone to restart. This is similar to holding the power button on a Macbook or laptop or just unplugging a device from power. You‚Äôll see this screen when you fix a frozen iPhone. You don‚Äôt need to hold the power buttons after the phone restarts. You should not lose any data doing this, but if you were typing a message, document or working on something inside of an app you may lose that small bit of work depending on when it saved. You don‚Äôt need to be plugged in to power or connected to a computer to use this method of fixing a frozen iPhone. If the battery is low, it may help to plug-in to power, but otherwise you are good to do this anytime the iPhone is frozen. Advertisement This works on any iPhone, iPad or iPod touch on any version of Apple‚Äôs software including iOS 5, iOS 6, iOS 7, iOS 8, iOS 9 and the upcoming iOS 10. Read: iOS 9 Tips and Tricks For users who consistently have this problem, it may be good to uninstall a problem app or make sure it is up to date. If you never restart your iPhone or iPad and you have this happen once or twice a year you can often avoid it by restarting you iPhone once every other week. If this is a continual problem you should consider backing up the iPhone to iCloud or your computer and then performing a factory reset. This takes longer to complete, but it can resolve problems. If you choose to to restore from an iPhone backup and the problem continues you may need to hard reset the iPhone and then set it up as a new device. You may then find it even harder to comprehend that the iPhone is only 10 years old - a landmark which it reaches today with the anniversary of its unveiling at the 2007 Macworld expo. Want to see the future being written? Feast your eyes on the late Steve Jobs below as he gives the world its first glimpse of the original iPhone: A lasting legacy Ambitious as it was to deliver ‚Äúa widescreen iPod with touch controls, a revolutionary mobile phone and a breakthrough internet communications device,‚Äù all in one back in 2007, it all seems rather quaint now - even down to the relative lack of bombast and polish that would surround a modern iPhone launch. Just check out poor Stan Sigman of Singular - he wouldn't get away with stumbling over flashcard prompts at a global Apple event these days. But Apple knew it was onto something special - today also marks the 10 years since it changed its name from Apple Computers Inc to simply Apple Inc, acknowledging that the lines between what a computer could be were about to change dramatically. ‚ÄúiPhone is an essential part of our customers' lives, and today more than ever it is redefining the way we communicate, entertain, work and live,‚Äù said Tim Cook, Apple‚Äôs current CEO, of the anniversary.¬† ‚ÄúiPhone set the standard for mobile computing in its first decade and we are just getting started. The best is yet to come.‚Äù Want to see where we're at now? TechRadar The source for Tech Buying Advice Search RSS Reviews How To Phones TVs Laptops Deals Photography More Car Tech Wearables Tablets Components Audiovisual Gaming Computing Downloads News Pro Trending Buying Guides Nintendo Switch iPhone 8 Samsung Galaxy S8 MacBook Pro MWC 2017 iOS 10.2 News How the iPhone has transformed over 10 years How the iPhone has transformed over 10 years By Luke Johnson Mobile phones ¬† There‚Äôs been a lot more than redesigns and added megapixels Shares Page 1 of 2: Screen size, resolution, build, camera and battery Screen size, resolution, build, camera and battery Power, storage, connections, software and connectivity It‚Äôs hard to believe that it‚Äôs a decade since the iPhone was first unveiled, such has been the impact of the first modern smartphone. On January 9 2007, when Steve Jobs took to the stage to show off this iPod / phone combo, the Motorola Razr V3 was the must-have handset, Nokia, BlackBerry and Sony Ericsson were all still a big deal, and the bulky, screen-sliding Telstra hiptop 2 was pegged as ‚Äúthe next big thing‚Äù. Flip phones were still popular, physical buttons obviously had to be there and a 3MP camera was considered to be extravagantly high-end. Now, however, almost all phones follow the foundations laid out by that original iPhone and we‚Äôve had 14 new models of Apple‚Äôs handset since then. But exactly how much has the iPhone changed over the past ten years? Despite being described at the time by Jobs as a ‚Äúmagical device‚Äù that would ‚Äúrevolutionize the industry,‚Äù what was announced on stage was hardly the best technology around - and by modern standards, it‚Äôs positively antiquated. So let‚Äôs see how much more power is packed into Apple‚Äôs most powerful phone, the iPhone 7 Plus, compared to the original. Screen size Pick up an original iPhone now and you‚Äôd wonder how we ever lived with such small, squat handsets. At the time, however, its 3.5-inch capacitive touchscreen (that accounted for 52% of the phone‚Äôs form) was a revolution. One of the first mainstream phones to fully trade in physical buttons for a touch panel, it offered an expanse of visual real estate unseen at the time. Today it‚Äôs more a surprise when a phone actually has keys, and screen sizes have expanded massively. The iPhone 7 Plus plays host to a large 5.5-inch panel, and that‚Äôs far from the biggest on the market. Though Apple resisted the trend for larger screen sizes for years. The original iPhone‚Äôs 3.5-inch form was retained from 2007 right up until 2012, and even then the iPhone 5 only adopted a 4-inch display. It was then a further two years before the 4.7-inch iPhone 6 launched alongside the 5.5-inch iPhone 6 Plus, which is still Apple‚Äôs biggest handset size today. Resolution Since the launch of the first iPhone, screens haven‚Äôt just got bigger, they‚Äôve become sharper, brighter, smarter and more vibrant too. The original iPhone‚Äôs 320 x 480 resolution packed in more pixels than anything else around at the time, but thanks to the much vaster screen size, its 165 pixels-per-inch image density wasn‚Äôt the sharpest. Now tech users are strapping screens with a similar resolution and much higher pixel density to their wrists, and phones like the iPhone 7 Plus are as pixel-rich as the TV that takes pride of place in your living room. The Plus‚Äôs 5.5-inch Retina HD display boasts a 1920 x 1080 resolution and 401ppi image density that, combined with a 1300:1 contrast ratio and boosted brightness over past models, make it Apple‚Äôs best-looking yet. While both phones run on capacitive touch (registering the finger‚Äôs electrical impulses rather than pressure to make the screen work), those touch elements have been enhanced and refined over the years. Improved multitouch capabilities have been added and now 3D Touch means the iPhone 7 Plus‚Äô screen is pressure sensitive too, comedically bringing back one of the features of early touchscreens that the first iPhone did away with. Build When the original iPhone was unveiled, its design and build was unlike anything seen on a phone, pairing an all-glass front with a largely metal back. Lining up at 11.6mm thick and 135g it stood out from a sea of flip phones, sliders and boxy candy bar handsets that all favored plastic over sweeping curves. A decade on, you can still see the original iPhone‚Äôs design DNA in the iPhone 7 Plus. At 7.3mm thick and 188g, the 7 Plus is finished with an all-metal body, in a choice of five colors. It‚Äôs also water-resistant to survive dips and dunks without succumbing to a liquid demise. Apple‚Äôs phones haven‚Äôt been without design flaws though: from the iPhone 4‚Äôs "just don‚Äôt hold it that way" Antennagate issues to the Bendgate woes that saw some iPhone 6 Plus models warping, the company‚Äôs hit a few design stumbling blocks along the way. Camera When the original iPhone was announced, cameras were still a luxury addition to smartphones. However, Apple was planning to compete with the best in the market with its expensive phone, and with devices such as the Sony Ericsson K800i already featuring 3MP snappers and the forthcoming Nokia N95 offering a huge 5MP sensor, the iPhone‚Äôs flash-less 2MP camera was a solid if far from ground-breaking addition. Now, the quality of the integrated camera is one of the main reasons we all buy new phones, and the iPhone 7 Plus has not one, but two sensors that take great photos - and that‚Äôs just on the back of the device. With the phone pairing a wide-angle, wide-aperture f/1.8 lens that helps boost the phone‚Äôs low-light photography skills with a second, f/2.8 telephoto lens that takes you closer to the action without degrading the image, the 7 Plus‚Äô dual-lens camera would have been unthinkable a decade ago - and Live Photos or 4K video recording would have caused the first iPhone‚Äôs CPU to melt. And where the original iPhone featured just the one camera, the iPhone 7 Plus has them both front and back - in 2007 selfie wasn‚Äôt even a word. Battery If the original iPhone‚Äôs screen, interface and design got people excited, its battery life filled any user with dread. Back in 2007, phone batteries were able to last around a working week between charges, and yet Apple had to convince users that daily recharges and just eight hours of talk time on a single charge was worth paying a small fortune for. The functionality of the phone won through, and now almost all smartphones are subjected to a nightly visit to a charger. The iPhone 7 Plus‚Äô oversized form has allowed a much bigger battery to be squeezed in - but despite almost tripling talk time to 21 hours, with so much more that the phone can do when it comes to web browsing, game playing and video streaming, you‚Äôll still be running out of battery come the end of the day - some things do never change. 1 2 Current page: Screen size, resolution, build, camera and battery Next Page Power, storage, connections, software and connectivity Tags iPhone Nokia Related news Windows 10 is about to slip in more stealthy adverts The best Nintendo 3DS deals in the January sales 2017 The best Sony Xperia X Compact deals in the January Sales 2017 BlackBerry partner says new tie-up won't be another Microsoft/Nokia debacle See more Mobile phones news Load Comments Tech deals, prizes and latest news Get the best tech deals, reviews, product advice, competitions, unmissable tech news and more! To celebrate the anniversary, Apple has launched a tribute page dedicated to the famous handset. In his keynote speech one decade ago, Jobs called the iPhone a ‚Äúrevolutionary product.‚Äù The former CEO described it as ‚Äúa widescreen iPod with touch controls, a revolutionary mobile phone and a breakthrough internet communications device.‚Äù¬† Since the first iPhone was released, Apple‚Äôs handsets have sold over one billion units worldwide. It became the inspiration for the iPad and, of course, the Apple Watch. The device also influenced the design and functions of smartphones¬†from other companies. In some cases, Apple felt the similarities were a little too close, leading to the seemingly never-ended patent lawsuits against Samsung. ‚ÄúiPhone set the standard for mobile computing in its first decade and we are just getting started.‚Äù said CEO Tim Cook. Much of Apple‚Äôs post is dedicated to the features and hardware found in the iPhone 7/7 Plus, which, while still a great phone and technically impressive, disappointed many Apple fans with its lack of innovation, similarities to the previous year‚Äôs model, and missing headphone jack. Despite its shortcomings, the newest iPhone was the top-selling US smartphone in the three months ending October 2016, taking a 10.6 percent share of the market - despite only being available for seven weeks out of that 12-week timeframe. Admittedly, though, some of its success could be attributed to Samsung‚Äôs Galaxy Note 7 nightmare. So what‚Äôs next for Apple? According to some alleged leaked manufacturing documents, 2017 will see the release of four new iPhones ‚Äì three ‚Äòs‚Äô models and the iPhone 8 (assuming that‚Äôs the name it will go by). Apple is rumored to be introducing a slew of new design features for its next flagship iPhone, including an almost edge-to-edge AMOLED display, embedded home button, wireless charging, and more. Cook believes the smartphone will be as revolutionary as the product Jobs introduced all those years ago. ‚ÄúThe best is yet to come,‚Äù said the current Apple boss. Search DABCC Mobile Apps Books LittleMsMobile.com ‚Äì Mobility News Top IT Videos Home Applications The Zen of data center maintenance The Zen of data center maintenance January 9, 2017 Veeam 0 0 Data centers have been around for a long time and are very important. Especially for me, as I sit here listening to Apple Music ‚Äî which is streaming from an Apple data center. The backups, applications and widgets you use every day are all made possible because there is a data center somewhere that supports them. We have learned which processes and procedures work based on what does or doesn‚Äôt go well. We‚Äôre going to look at some different maintenance activities today, but we‚Äôll also discuss data center outages to see what we can learn. Planned maintenance In the past, you had to make an appointment (usually late at night or on a weekend) to update things like firmware or operating systems. It‚Äôs important to note that this was a scheduled process and passed change control and change configuration. I prefer to avoid doing things the old way if possible! Preventive maintenance Preventive maintenance is a proactive activity. It could be installing more memory on a server or adding a server to a cluster. These tasks are often completed as a part of a planned data center maintenance period.
